Authors:
Rachel Anne Koch, D. Jean Lodge, Susanne Sourell, Austin G
McCoy, Mary Catherine Aime, Karen K Nakasone
Title:
Tying up loose threads: Revised taxonomy and phylogeny of an
avian-dispersed Neotropical rhizomorph-forming fungus
Keywords:
Agaricales, Campanella, Fungal systematics, Marasmius,
Phytopathogenic fungi, Tetrapyrgos
Abstract:
Rhizomorpha corynecarpos Kunze was originally described
from wet forests in Suriname. This unusual fungus forms white, sterile,
rhizomorphs bearing abundant club-shaped branches. Its evolutionary
origins are unknown because sexual structures were never found. Recent
collections and observations of R. corynecarpos were made from Belize,
Brazil, Ecuador, Guyana and Peru. Phylogenetic analyses of three nuclear
rDNA regions (internal transcribed spacer, large ribosomal subunit and
small ribosomal subunit) were conducted to resolve the phylogenetic
relationship of R. corynecarpos. Results show this fungus is sister to
Brunneocorticium bisporumÂ—a widely distributed, tropical crust fungus.
These two taxa along with Neocampanella blastanos, form a clade of crust
fungi within the primarily mushroom-forming Marasmiaceae. Based on
phylogenetic evidence and micromorphological similarities, we propose
the new combination, Brunneocorticium corynecarpon, to accommodate this
species. Brunneocorticium corynecarpon is a pathogen, infecting the
crowns of trees and shrubs in the Neotropics; the long, dangling
rhizomorphs with lateral prongs probably colonize neighboring trees.
Longer-distance dispersal can be accomplished by birds as it is used as
construction material in nests of various bird species.
